Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gilbratar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Moday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at he very convienient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returnin within 12 months.
In addition to the above weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marsielles
TO THE EAST

The mail steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightlyy, and another for Japan. Passnegers embark at Port Said.

div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for return from SUAKIN every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves SUEZ for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAB, ADEN. div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find a special though carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: DOMESTIC ECONOMY IN CYPRUS.
div.p: It is a common but very erroneous supposition that Cyprus is a happy land where all the ordinary needs of the body are to be had almost without money and without price, and where an ample and comfortable standard of living is compatible with a very low rate of expenditure. Previous to the British Occupation this, no doubt, was true enough, and British officials then residing there, and in receipt of ordinary rates of pay, must have found it possible to live well within their official incomes. Even now the standard of living among the native Cypriots remains very largely what it always was, and, with the exception of some few who have travelled or resided abroad and have acquired Western ideas, the domestic economy of the average native is on a far humbler scale than that of the same class"in European countries. The fact that prices of household commodities have risen does not materially affect, therefore, the Cypriot. It should be understood that the bulk of the Cypriots are either agricultural producers or merchants, and even the few professional men are also mostly owners of chiftliks, and therefore all classes of the native community are more or less directly benefited by an increase in the price of locally raised commodities.
This rise in the prices of articles of local production, while directly benefiting the native producer and merchant, is a very serious matter indeed to the unfortunate British offi­

cial, to whose altruistic labours in the past this improvement in trade, with its accompanying advance in market values, is principally due. Cyprus has come to be regarded by British officials in other colonies as a veritable Paradise towards which they cast longing eyes, and in which they are willing to accept service at half the rate of pay which obtains in other parts of the Empire. It may be a kindness to them to point out that this is entirely a fiction. Those residents with fixed incomes, such as officials dependent on their pay, have a most anxious and difficult task in making both ends meet There is probably no Crown Colony in which the pay of Government officials is on so low a scale, and yet what are the ruling prices to-day of some of the leading articles of consumption ? For the benefit of those unacquainted with the local coinage the English equivalent is given:—(the oke equals 2 4/5 lbs.) Beef 1s. 4d. per oke ; mutton 1s.

6 1/2d. per oke; eggs three for 1 1/4d.; wood and fuel, unchopped, 7s. per donkey load, chopping 1s. extra; butter 2s. 3d. to 2s. 8d. per lb.; servants’ wages: cooks £2 to £3 per month; houseboys 30s. to 50s. per month, exclusive of food which is always supplied to them. House rent ranges from £25 to £60 per annum; scarcely a house can be found outside the town for less than £30 p.a., and for sanitary reasons most English object to living within the city walls. The above prices may not appear' high to those accustomed to European prioes, and with incomes commensurate to a higher rate of living, but they are considerably higher than they were at the time the present rate of official salaries was fixed, and not only so but for purposes of comparison the quality of the goods must be taken into account. Good meat is rarely obtainable, and the botchers have no knowledge of their work. Beef is rot often to be found at all, and is usually so tough (the carcases of worn-out draught animals) as to be barely eatable. At this season lamb is sold as mutton, and the joints, which are minute, oonsist of bone and gristle, all of which is charged for at full rates. The lambs are killed so young that they have no flesh on their bones whatever.

As regards domestio servants, many of the older ones are well acquainted with their work, but the younger servants who have everything to learn are certainly dear at the price, and with increasing values all round the tendency is for their wages to be raised. To put the case moderately it is just possible for an Englishman and his Wife to live in reasonable comfort on an income of £225 a year. This presupposes constant care and vigilance on the part of the housewife, and that she is sufficiently acquainted with the language and with the many arts and dodges of the wily native, not to be imposed upon by her servants and tradespeople; a condition of things which is naturally rarely met with. This allows no margin whatever for sickness, or for travelling expenses to and from England on leave of absence, and certainly allows no opportunity of saving, such as every official should be able to do. It may be added that a large number of official posts in Cyprus of good status worth from £500 to £800 a year elsewhere and held by English gentlemen accustomed to the ordinary standard of living which obtains in England, carry salaries ranging only from £150 to £300 per annum.

It should be stated that the cost of living is many times greater than it was in the early lays ot the occupation, after the first rush had subsided, when day labour was obtainable at 2 1/2 piastres (3d.) a day, instead of 1s. a day as now, and when meat was at 3 to 5 piastres (4d. to 6 1/2d.) an oke. The enhanced prioes betoken the development of the trade of the country, but it surely must be time for the salaries of the unfortunate officials to be reconsidered, as has lately been done here in Egypt

From the foregoing it will be seen that while living may still be regarded as cheap in that Island for those whose inoomes are from, say, £400 upwards, it is quite the reverse for those who, transplanted from countries where the standard of living whioh they have been born and bred in is high, now find themselves in positions of trust and responsibility and onerous work and in receipt of salaries inadequate to meet the necessary claims upon them.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Aida Sails.
H.H.S. Aida left Alexandria this morning for Port Said, en route to Akaba.
Judicial Adviser’s Report.
The Judicial Adviser’s report will be pub­lished in to-night’s "Journal Officiel.”
Cairo Barbers' Strike.
We hear that the barbers’ assistants at Cairo have gone on strike and demand shorter hours and longer intervals for meals. Alexandria's example is being followed at Cairo.
Slave Dealers Sentenced.

The nine slave-dealers who were recently arrested on the R«d Sea Coast after wounding a coast-guard and offering armed resistance to the authorities, have been tried by court martial at Assouan and sentenced to fifteen years’ imprisonment with hard labour.
Egyptian Sugar and Land Co.

Some of our readers will notice with a painful interest the advertisement in to-day’s issue announcing that a meeting of the share-­holders of the Egyptian Sugar and Land Company is to be held shortly to hear the report of the liquidator on the progress of the liquidation.
Bank of Egypt.

The new agency of the above bank at Che-bin-el-Kom was opened at mid-day on Saturday last by the general manager, Com. Augusto Luzzatto, in the presence of the Moudir and notables of the district. Messrs. Gelat and Natsios have been appointed agents at the new agency.
Connaught House.

There will be some enjoyable music at the concert to be held at Connaught House Y. W. C. A., Cairo, on Thursday, 15th inst., for the following are kindly giving their services: vocalists, Miss Bullock, Miss Lefroy, Mrs. Roussin; instrumentalists, Mrs. Du Boulay (piano), Mrs. Nolan (harp), Miss M. Lefroy (violin), Herr Otto (’oello). The conoert will commence at 3.30 p.m.
Alexandria Archaeological Society.

The latest Bulletin of the Alexandria Archaeological Society is a very readable number, the only drawback being that it demands an acquaintance with four languages, four of the articles being in Italian, three in English,two in French, and two in German.The following is a list of the contributors and the subject matter of their articles : Borchardt — Von einer alexandrinischen Baustelle ; Edgar —A Terracotta from Mendes ; Lefebvre—Epitaphes de moines alexandrins ; Rubensohn— Ausgrabungen in Abusir-el-Ma'aq; Grenfell Hunt—The fourth Season at Oxyrhynchus ; Blomfield—The Arsinoeum and its Obelisk ; Breccia—Un gruppo di tombe presso Hadra ; Breccia E.—La Necropoli di Sciatbi; Dattari— Monete trovate nella necropoli di Sciatbi; Breccia—Antiquites decouvertes a Maamourah par S.A. le prince Omar Pacha Toussoun ; Breccia—Cronaca del Museo et degli scavi eritrovamenti nel territorio di Alessandria.

div.head: CAIRO LAW SCHOOL.
div.p: AN ULTIMATUM.
THREAT OF ANOTHER STRIKE.

We regret to hear that the pupils of the Khedivial Law School have not profited by their recent experiences. An ultimatum was sent to the Ministry of Public Instruction last week demanding the reinstatement of the four expelled pupils and threatening another strike if the Ministry refused to comply. The demand, was refused by the Ministry and the official reply read to the students, who made no demonstration.

It is to be hoped that they will have the sense to see that any farther outbreaks must lead to the dosing of the Law School and to the permanent injury of their careers. We should like to point out to those of them who are not above taking European advice that their guides have not been ge­nuine educational reformers, but political wire-pullers whom—in a fatal moment for themselves—they allowed to take over the direction of the movement. Is it worth their while to handicap themselves and inflict great inconvenience on their parents to enable Mustapha Pacha Kamel to pose as the leader of the Egyptian youth? But perhaps that energetic patriot has promised them all places as printer’s devils and proof-readers in the office of the "Lewa.”

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION.
div.p: We are still in the dark about the frontier. The Turkish troops, despite the assurances of the home Press, are still in possession of Tabah and the Nekb el-Akaba, the Turkish delegates. Miralai Muzaffer Bey and Bimbashi Fehmi, have departed without a word, and we hear that one of the Egyptian delegates is now mournfully surveying a complete camping outfit which he acquired on learning that he might have to start for the frontier almost immediately. The Diana remains off Akaba, and Mr. Bramley awaits events at Nakhl. Meantime the probability of an increase in the Turkish forces on the frontier grows greater day by day, and with it the necessity of a complete delimitation of the frontier which will prevent the recurrence of similar incidents.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The following are the decisions of the Coun­cil of Ministers which met on Saturday at Abdeen Palace under the presidency of H H. the Khedive :

Transfer of Abd-el-Mpssih Bey Simaika, judge of the Mansourah Mixed Court, to the Alexandria Mixed Court.
Appointment of Youssef Bey Suleiman to be judge of the Mansourah Mixed Court.
Approval of a law authorising the Minis­try of the Interior in cases when the country is threatened with epidemic disease to take the necessary measures with regard to the transport of rags.
Appointment of Mr. Rowlatt to the Governorship of the National Bank of Egypt and of Mr. Home to the Sub-Governorship.
Authorisation of numerous minor public works in the Markazes of Keneb, Mansourah. Minieh, and Tahta, and of the construction of 26 agricultural roads in various parts of Upper Egypt,

div.head: THE SUCERIES.
div.p: THE APPEAL CASE.
PLEADINGS FOR THE CONCORDAT.

This morning, the appeal of the Societe des Sucreries et de la Ruffinerie d’Egypte came on for hearing before the First Chamber of the Mixed Appeal Court, under the presidency of Judge de Korizmics. Maitre Carton de Wiart opened the ease with a masterly review of the whole history of the affair. He began with the efforts of Ismail Pacha to encourage the cultivation of the sugar cane in Egypt and dealt with the history of the rise and development of the Company, the suicide and bank­ruptcy of M. Cronier, and the subsequent crisis, with the details of which our readers are well acquainted. The eminent counsel went on to show that if the bankruptcy had been declared at the time of the Cronier crash, the Daira Sugar Corporation could have absorbed almost the whole of the Sucreries and the bondholders would have received thirty or forty per cent., while the shareholders would have received nothing. On the 19th September the Cairo Court selected the experts and the report of those gentlemen was undoubtedly considerably influenced by the tendencies of a section of public opinion. The former employes of the company also foment­ed a fierce agitation against the Suoreries. The result was that the experts were un­doubtedly influenced by these tendencies while French experts, on the other hand, were in favour of the reconstitution of the company, and their opinion was maintained by such authorities as Harari Pacha and Boghos Pacha Nubar, who were ready to join the board of a reconstituted company. As to the report of the Cairo experts, it was nothing more nor less than a “ requisitoire. ” They had declared that the company was neither un­fortunate nor of good faith. When the counsel for the company wished to reply to the experts, the Court refused to grant him a hearing. Meanwhile at Paris an agreement had been arrived at by all the parties interested to accept a “Concordat preventif,” The agreement was that of the total debt, £850,600, no less than £400,00 would be wiped off by accepting the offer of the Egyptian Govern­ment to take over the company’s line of rail­way, £400,000 would be covered by the issue of debenture stock, and £400,000 by a further issue which would extinguish the small balance of debt remaining and enable the company to proceed with its business. The attitude of the "Ministere Public” at Cairo was utterly incomprehensible and the point of view of that gentleman was curious in the extreme. Why, when everybody, creditors and shareholders alike, was unanimous in demand­ing a “concordat,” how came it that the Mi­nistere Public sprang upon an astonished world the preposterous demand for bankruptcy When Maitre Padoa Bey, counsel for the creditors, rose to reply, as he had the right to for the pronouncement of the Ministere Public was a “demande nouvelle” and also contained some erroneous points, the Court refused him a hearing. As to the finding of the lower Court, Maitre Carton not only claimed that the Court of Appeal should quash the judgment but that it should decree the “homologation du concordat.” The important point was that the bad faith of the board of directors should be established, if bankruptcy was to be declared. This important point the experts had failed to substantiate sati-factorily.

They had confined themselves to taking the opinions of the petty employes of the company and never once had asked the ad vice of their chiefs. Moreover, the several reports of these gentlemen were contradictory, and in order that they should present a joint report to the Tribunal they had simply struck a mean between their variouspoints of view. Maitre Carton indignantly stigmatised such conduct, especially in such a case, when the honour of the directors, the future of the company, and a most im­portant industry in Egypt were at stake. Leaving out Cronier, de la Bouglise, and Leroux, who alone can be accused of complicity, the others could not be accused of bad faith. The lower Court in its judgment declared that the shareholders had abdicat­ed their rights on the pretext that the com­pany’s meetings were specially attended by the shareholders, but this line of argument was illogical, as no less than 300,000 shares of a total of 825,000 were held in France. At many company meetings a quorum is not attained but this is not equivalent to an abrogation of their rights by the share holders. The two “arrets” of a Belgian Court, in which the Cairo Tribunal based its judg­ment. rather supported his own contention, said Maitre Carton, than that of the Court. The first of these “arrets” declared that bankruptcy ought to ensue, but among the "attendus” there was one to the effect that bank­ruptcy was in the interests of the creditors.
Maitre Padoa Bey than spoke for the creditors and showed that a concordat should be granted in the interests of the creditors.

M. Borchgrevink, Procureur General, de­clared that the Board had been guilty of carelessness and grave negligence for years past. He disputed the validity of the “arbitrage” and concluded that inasmuch as the Board and the general meetings are the recognised instruments whereby the company acts, it is logical that the company should be held responsible for the deeds of its Board, and he was consequently in favour of confirming the judgment of the lower Court.
Judgment will be given on the 21st inst.

div.head: THE HELOUAN BALL.
div.p: PICTURESQUE AND GAY SCENE.
SOME OF THE COSTUMES WORN.

The present season at Helouan has been one of the best on record. On Friday last, the Grand Hotel Helouan, which has always taken the leading part in providing amuse­ments for visitors, presented a wonderfully picturesque and gay scene, the special oc­casion being a fancy-dress ball. To Mr. Petry, the courteous manager, a special feeling of thanks most have been felt by all present for the excellent way in which the prepa­rations had been made. The floor, which is undoubtedly one of the best in Egypt, was in splendid order and the buffet provided was laden with delicacies. The music was supplied by Bracale’s Band, who kept ex­cellent time and had to pay penalty by numerous “encores.” Many dinner parties had been given. Among those entertaining were Mr. and Mrs. R. H. Shelmerdine, Mrs. Bell White, Capt. and Mrs. Slazanger, Mr. and Mrs. Sargent, Mrs. Warren, Dr. Llewellyn Phillips, Capt. Adams and others. Dr. and Miss Hobson entertained Miss Babington Jones, Mr. Trimen, Mr. Nesbit and Mr.Dickenson at dinner before the dance, and Dr. Bentley came with a large party from the Tewfik Palace Hotel. The visitors from Cairo who were present, through the courtesy of Captain Adams, were able to return to Cairo by special train at 1.30 a.m.

Helouan has often been accused of being full of invalids, and being far too dull for sound and healthy persons. If that is so, such a statement was entirely disproved on Friday night. The opening dance provided an ex­tremely pretty eight, for the costumes, many of which were extremely clever, presented a kaleidoscope of colours and the scene was watched with interest by numbers of non-dancing visitors from the different hotels and pensions who had been cordially invited. The following are some of the costumes. Miss Zabotkine wore one of the prettiest costaues of the evening, appearing ae a pierette in red, and white, and her sister was a baby in a long lace robe, Miss Warren,early Viotorian; Miss Jones, Mrs. Warren and Miss Totenham, Gipsies; Miss Fawcett, a dainty Geisha ; Miss Darley and Miss Duncan looked charming, the former as a rose, the latter as Duchess of Devonshire; Miss Babington J. Jones as a lady of the last century and her pretty young sister represent­ing Cherry Ripe; Miss Hobson a school-girl of unknown date ; Miss Kirkbright was much noticed as Folly; Mrs. Beckett, Poudre ; Miss Gladys Phillips, dainty Chinese Lady ; Miss Bentley, milkmaid; Miss Philipps, a flower girl. Mr. Mannel and Seligman amused their many friends as Casino girls in somewhat gaudy dresses. Mr. Shelmerdine, chef. Mr. Firth a donkey boy. Dr. Bremner a tennis player fitted with all requirements. Capt. Outran, Order of the Bath. Mr. Charlesworth and his brother a masked gentleman and countryman in a blue smock respectively. Dr. Bentley looked very well as a sheikh, Mr. Bentley jockey; Mr. Sawyer, doctor of music ; Mr. de Cosson,Sir Walter Raleigh, Dr Phillips; 18th Centnry Beau; Mr. Trimers and Mr. Dic­kenson, Anglo- 'mericans; Mr. Nesbit’s costume was particularly striking as a stately Bedouin. Dr. O. Hobson’s costume as Winter was ex­tremely effective Mr. Warren and many others added to the gay scene. In evening dress we noticed Mrs. and Miss Crofton, Capt. Adams, the Messrs. Bennet, Mr. Loftua. Cant. Gordon Cumming, Mr. and Mrs. Firth. Mr. and Mrs. Straker, who were all indefatigable dancers.

div.head: TURKISH GUNBOATS AT SUEZ.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Suez. Saturday.

Two Turkish gunboats Osctani apd Yetba, with the supplyship Edremi,came out of the ca­nal this morning and will sail early to morrow morning for Hodeidah. The tonnage of the gunboats is 184 tons, their crew 42 all told, and they carry four quick-firing guns.
The British second-class cruiser Hyacinth arrived at Suez this afternoon from the East Indies, where she has been relieved by the Hermes.
All steamers arriving from the South report a very strong northerly gale in the Red Sea, on account of which they are considerably detained.
The Japanese mailboat lye Maru is expected to arrive at Suez this evening from Japan, bound to London. She is the first to renew the service sinCe the war.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF AMERICAN WARSHIPS.
div.p: The American men-of-war, Brooklyn, Ta­coma, and Chattanooya arrived at Alexandria from Beyrout early this morning and ex­changed the usual salutes with Fort Saleh. The squadron is under the command of Admi­ral Sigsbee.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive will receive the func-tionaries and notables who received decorations of the higher grades on the last anniversary of his accession at 3 p.m. on Friday next at Abdeen.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Senegal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and Is due here to-morrow.

div.head: NEW BRITISH CLUB.
div.p: FORMAL OPENING CEREMONY.
CLUB COMMITTEE “AT HOME.”

When, a few months since, the idea origin­ated of presenting a British Club to Alexandria, no one dared hope that the scheme would meet with the success it has. Merchants bankers, shipping companies, and individuals all came to the front with valuable aid, with the result that last Saturday afternoon the committee were enabled to formally open the club.

The committee were "At Home’’ from 4.30 to 7.80 p.m., during which time many hundreds of persons availed themselves of the opportunity of inspecting the club’s beautiful premises, which are very handsomely equipped. The billiard-rooms are second to none, the card- room and lounge are appropriately furnished, and the electric installation is perfect The floral decorations, which were very tasteful and gave a bright appearance to the club, were very kindly arranged by Mrs. Gould, wife of the Consul-General, and donations of flowers were kindly made by Mr. Percy Carver and Mrs. Crafton. Refreshments were served continuously during the At Home and suitable music was furnished by D’Ambra’s orchestra.

Amongst the many present we noticed Sir Massle and Lady Blomfield, Mr. and Mrs. E. B. Gould, Mr. Percy Carver, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Carver, Mr. and Mrs. Crafton, Canon and Mrs. Ward, Rev. H. P. and Mrs. Reid and many others, too numerous to mention, all of whom were conducted through the premises by the committee, and the same flattering remarks were heard on all sides, viz., that the club far surpassed all anti­cipations.

A general meeting of members was held at 9 p.m., Mr. J. Davies Bryan in the chair, when the new rules were passed. Mr. Kerr was elected hon. auditor, and Mr. Francis Leveaux hon. legal adviser to the club.

Mr. P. W. Carver, as hon. treasurer, gave a brief outline of the present finances of the club. There are now 223 members, of whom 205 are ordinary and country members, and 18 have given special annual subscriptions amounting to L.E. 100 Donations collected are L.E. 921. The expenditure has been care­fully made end a credit balance of about L.E. 240 exists at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, besides £200 of Unified. There is, however, a further outlay in prospect to complete the furnishing, and the second portion of the rent, L.E. 220, to be met. Enough was shown to satisfy the meeting that the club is on a sound financial basis.

Votes of thanks were accorded to Sir Massie Blomfield, chairman of the original committee, Mr, Percy Carver, the hon. treasurer, Mr. Arthur Purvis, the hon seoretaiy, Mr. Davies Bryan, chairman of the committee, Mr. Geo. Morris, late chairman of the house committee, and Mr. Walter Sarjeant, present chairman of the house committee.

So ended a very pleasant and memorable occasion. The club, so much needed and now so auspiciously inaugurated, is now at the disposal of those it was intended for. The committee have done their work well ; it only now remains for the members to support it

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: SALE AT 100 PER CENT. PROFIT.

Last week the above company disposed of 14,000 pics of land on the Mahmoudieh Canal at P.T. 110 per pic, for which they had paid P.T. 54, this giving the company a profit of 100 per cent, on their transaction.

div.head: THE MANOEUVRES.
div.p: Brigadier General G M. Bullock, C.B., Com­manding the Force in Egypt Major A R. Hoskins, D.S.O., Major. General Staff, Lieut.- Colonel R. C. Cox and Captain J. Evans, 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, left Cairo by the 6 a m. train to-day for Khatatba, for duty during the manoeuvres.
The Machine Gun Detachment 1st.Batta­lion King’s Royal Rifle Corps, consisting of 10 N.C.O.’s and men, also 6 horses and 2 mules, will proceed from Cairo to Khatatba by rail to-day.

div.head: PERRIER WATER.
div.p: The universal satisfaction that this natural table water appears to be giving not only in Egypt but all over the world is remarkable. It certainly meets the requirements of most, and is especially suitable for the climate and condi­tions which rule in Egypt.

div.head: EGYPT AND THE WHITE STAR LINE.
div.p: Readers of this paper will observe in our advertising columns particulars of the sailings of the White Star Line from Alexnadria to Naples (reached in four days) and America. This service is undoubtedly one of the best for reachin Europe, and should be well patronised be the many travellers now in Egypt, and who will soon be contemplating their return jorney.
The immediate sailings are:
and the fares are from ALexandria to Naples are 10 and upwards. Bookings may be effectedd at the White Star Agents in Alexandria, Messrs. J. Ross and Co., and at Cook's Tourist Offices in Cairo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Archduke Joseph of Austria and suite made a short stay at the Luxor Hotel on their way up to Assouan last night.
We are glad to announce the birth of a son and heir to Mr. Fred. T. Rowlatt, Governor of the National Bank of Egypt, which took place at Cairo yesterday. Both mother and child are doing well.
Major F. W. Hardy, R.A.M.C., has been granted leave of absence from the 23rd inst. to July 22, with permission to travel in Italy, Switzerland, France, and England.

The Right Rev. Robert Brindle, D.S.O., Roman Catholic Bishop of Nottingham, who officiated at the conversion of Princess Ena, had a long career as military chaplain before the Cardinal Vaughan made him an auxiliary bishop in the Archdiocese of Westminster. He was with Lord Kitchener in the final conquest of the Sudan and recited a prayer of his own composition at the memorial service for General Gordon in Khartoum. It so impressed Lord Kitchener that he had a number of copies struck off. Lord Kitchener and previous commanders in the Sudan had a high opinion of Father Brindle’s judgment, and often consulted him.

Departures for the South still continue to be numerous. The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Saturday : Mr. Mettke, Dr. Vogel, Mr. and Mrs. Weiler, Mr. and Mrs. Mallaben, Comte Ahlefeldt,Mr. and Mrs. Steckney, Miss Stickey, Miss Maxon, Mr. Spenoer Broarn, Mr. H. div.head: A COLLECTION OF WATER COLOUR SKETCHES.
div.p: Mr. A. O. Lamplough, A.M.S.K., has re­turned from his trip to the Fayoum, and has added various fresh and altogether delightful sketches to those already on view at the National Hotel. Mr. Lamplough has been particularly happy in catching the Egyptian atmosphere, and more especially so in gauging both that translucent colouring and mist effect which make our morning and our evening glory. There are two delightful bits of Fayonm town, which are worth remember­ing and are very delicately handled, and there is a hot sunny stretch of road with huts at one side and some cool grey palms in the mid distance which is also very good. The lovely fisher hut on Lake Kurn, where duty is levied on the fish caught therein,is not without its charm, and there are many who would appreciate that lovely stretch of Libyan desert with nothing but its rocks to break its drear monotony.

It is rather late to speak of the collection of pictures which has already been on view now for some weeks, but there is much merit in these water-colours, and they deserve appreciation. The stretches of the river about Luxor, whether in the morning cool, midday sun, or sunset, are full of charm, and there is a wealth of colour in No. 10. where the sun is tinging the low hills with its glow, and the dababeah is floating down the shallow reaches. The mist effects on the Nile and in the desert are treated with great simplicity and effect, and there are various views of the country in which the Pyramids appear as background. A very careful piece of drawing with masterly treatment of reflected shadows is to be seen in No. 25, “Court of the Nile Temple,’’ at Medinet Haba. A similar picture to this was bought last year by H.R.H. Princess Henry of Battenberg, who has favoured Mr. Lamp- lough on several occasion*. Those who are interested in the country and who have a keen appreciation of its beauties should not miss this opportunity of seeing this charming collection.

div.head: TO-DAYS TELEGRAMS.
div.p: TERRIBLE MINING EXPLOSION.
AN UNPARALLED CATASTROPHE.
ENORMOUS LOSS OF LIFE.
Lille, March 10. 1
A terrible explosion occurred, owing to fire- damp, in the Courrieres coalmine near here. 1,800 men were in the mine. Some have been rescued but it is feared the loss of life is enormous. (Reuter)
Paris, March 10.
A catastrophe has taken place in the mines at Lens (Pas de Calais). Eighteen hundred miners had gone down in the morning. It is feared there are numerous victims. (Havai)
Lens, March 10.
The number of dead known np to the pre­sent is 1,219. (Havas)
Lille, March 11.

The Courrieres catastrophe is unparalleled in the whole history of mining. 1.219 persons are known to have been killed. A crowd of 25,000 persons have struggled to the pitheads endeavouring to learn the fate of their bread­winners. It appears that the fire had been smouldering for days in the lower workings. It broke out furiously yesterday morning at 700 feet below the surface, resulting in explosions.

The rescue work is most difficult and dangerous, owing to the galleries caving in and being full of poisonous gases. Hundreds of bodies have been recovered. Subscriptions for the sufferers are coming in freely. The Chamber will be asked to vote 500,000 francs. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SPANISH MARRIAGE.
div.p: PRINCESS ENA’S CONVERSION.
London, March 10.

The "Times” cordially felicitates King Alfonso and Princess Ena and dwells on the political advantages of the marriage, bat it adds that it is idle to pretend that in the religious sense the nation wholly approves of the conversion of a Protestant. England will not welcome any confessors in Buckingham Palace or State ceremonies at Westminster Cathedral (Reuter)

div.head: THE ARMY ESTIMATES.
div.p: RADICALS FAVOUR REDUCTION.

London, March 1C A section of the Ministerialists are disappointed at there being no reduction in Army Estimates: consequently Mr. Seely poses to move a reduction of 6,000 men, when the Army votes come before the house. (R.)
London, March 10

It understood that the debate on the Army Estimates next week will take a wide range, A strong feeling is apparent among the Radicals in favour of reduction, especially in India in view of the Japanese Alliance crippling Russia. The hope is expressed, in view of Mr. Haldane’s speech, that he will be disposed to concur.(Reuter)

div.head: MR. BALFOUR BETTER.
div.p: London, March 10
Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain have recovered and will participate in the fiscal debate on Monday next. (Reuter)

div.head: WOMEN SUFFRAGISTS.
div.p: PREMIER’S RESIDENCE BESI8GEE

London, March 11 A crowd of women suffragists besieged Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman’s residence yesterday demanding an interview, but were not admitted. Police dispersed the gathering Three women were arrested but released on caution. (R.)

div.head: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
div.p: COMPROMISE ON BANK QUE3TION.
Algeciras, March 10.
A compromise has been reached on the Bank St question. (Reuter)
Algeciras, March 11.

Mr. Radowitz announced at yesterday’s con- ference that Germany renounced the essential part of her demands with regard to the police question. He advised that the French and Austrian schemes should be referred to a committee to be harmonized
(Reuter)

div.head: NEW FRENCH CABINET.
div.p: M. SARRIEN MEETING DIFFICULTIES.
Paris, March 10.
M. Sarrien has agreed to form a Cabinet.
(Reuter)

The Sarrien combination continues. Bourgeois will take the portfolio of Foreign Affairs Ars. (Bavat) N
Paris, March 11.
M. Sarrien is actively engaged in forming a Cabinet but is encountering difficulties. (Reuter)
Paris, March 11.
It is probable M. Clemenceau will form part of the Ministry with the portfolio of the Interior.
(Havas)

div.head: RIGA-KHERSIN CANAL.
div.p: AMERICAN SCHEME APPROVED
St. Petersburg, March 10.
The Russian Government approves of the scheme of American financiers to construct a look canal between Riga and Kherson. (R.)

div.head: EARTHQUAKE IN INDIA.
div.p: London, March 10.
Eight persons were killed and 26 injured owing to an earthquake in the Bashahr district. One person was also killed at Simla. (Reuter)

The new tube railway between Waterloo and Baker Street was opened to-day. (Reuter)

div.head: NEW BOOKS.
div.p: One of the most useful series of books for English-speaking folk abroad is Hutchinson’s Colonial Library. Among the latest publications of this series is “The Gambler” by Katherine Thurston. Messrs. G. G. Zacharia & Co., of “The English Library,” Cairo, have a large stock of volumes of this sensational novel as a big rush for this work is expected.

Mrs. Thurston’s new novel is as great an achievement as was "John Chilcote, M.P.” It is striking and original, and the heroine, a beautiful Irish girl, is as fascinating as she is on uncommon. The story deals in a dramatic and exciting manner with an impoverished Irish mal family of the better class. The head of the house is a gambler, and Clodagh, bright, gay, impulsive, bat the soul of honour, inherits his passion. The scenes shift from Ireland to the Continent, where Clodagh goes with a husband whom she has married almost without thought on her father’s death. The love is awakened inher by another, and intrigues, debts and diffi­culties beset her, but she is saved when rain seems coming. Clodagh is so intensely human and loveable in her strength and weakness alike that there is from first to last a compelling interest in the story.

Messrs. Methuen and Co. have just published (2s. 6d.) an excellent primer of religion based on the catechism of the Church of England. Ion The author is the Rev. W. T. Oldfield, Pre­bendary of Lincoln, who his produced a most serviceable little book, which will form a practical basis for the religious instruction of the young. The style is simple and the method of presentation is unexceptionable. Wecordially recommend this handbook to our Anglican readers.
